metadata.title: Core-shell magnetic nanomaterial grafted spongy-structured poly (ionic liquid): A recyclable brönsted acid catalyst for biodiesel production

Core-shell magnetic nanomaterial grafted spongy-structured poly (ionic liquid): A recyclable brönsted acid catalyst for biodiesel production Jing Ding Conceptualization Investigation Writing - original draft Resources Chengwei Zhou Investigation Writing - original draft Zuowang Wu Investigation Writing - original draft Chong Chen Investigation Nengjie Feng Resources Lei Wang Resources Hui Wan Supervision Project administration Writing - review & editing * Guofeng Guan Project administration Resources Project administration Funding acquisition * State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu National Synergetic Innovation Center for Advanced Materials, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, P. R. China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Construction of an efficient and separable Bronsted acid catalyst to realize one-pot conversion from low-value oils to biodiesel has been a hot and difficult spot in recent years. Herein, a novel magnetically recyclable catalyst was fabricated by grafting the sponge-like structure of poly (ionic liquid) on the surface of support Fe3O4/SiO2. The grafting copolymerization of dual-acidic ionic liquid (sulfonated vinylimidazolium ionic liquid) on the Fe3O4/SiO2 was beneficial to enhance the strong acidity of the magnetic carrier and also made dual-acidic ionic liquid own excellent separation characteristics. The characterization results of the prepared composite showed that a sponge-like structure of poly(ionic liquid) was wrapped on the outer surface of Fe3O4@SiO2, thereby providing more active sites to reactants. Meanwhile, the catalyst possessed high magnetization value (14.3 emu/g) that resulted in the simple and rapid separation from the reaction system through an external magnetic field. Benefiting from the synergy effect between dual-acidic poly(ionic liquids) and magnetic carrier, Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL exhibited good catalytic performance with the oleic acid conversion of 92.1 % and the methyl oleate yield of 92.1 %. Besides, the recycled catalyst showed no significant loss in the catalytic activity after repeated use for six times. Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Poly(ionic liquid) Fe3O4/SiO2 Esterification Biodiesel 1 Introduction Biodiesel, by vitue of its properties such as sustainability, biodegradability and non-toxicity, has been one of the best renewable energy sources in contrast with petroleum-based diesel [1–3]. Biodiesel can be obtained by alkali- or acid-catalyzed esterification and transesterification reactions [4–6]. Compared with the characteristics of alkali-catalysis that owns strict requirements on the raw materials, acid catalyst can simultaneously proceed the esterification and transesterification reactions without saponification [7,8]. However, the conventional acid catalyst is always facing the problems of the equipment corrosion, environmental damage and poor reusable performance. Many efforts have been made to seek for novel catalysts [9]. Ionic liquids (ILs), based on their remarkable characteristics such as negligible volatility and the structural design, have gained extensive attentions [10–12]. As an acid catalyst with good catalytic performance, -SO3H functionalized strong Brønsted acid ionic liquids can take the place of conventional acid catalysts that are applied to acid-catalyzed reactions such as esterification and transesterification [13,14]. Unfortunately, ionic liquids also suffer from some disadvantages such as high viscosity, difficult separation of catalyst in homogeneous system [15–17], etc. Therefore, the strategy of immobilization of acidic ionic liquids on different supports (porous silica, MOFs, polystyrene-based polymers, etc.) has been proposed to construct heterogeneous acid catalyst systems [18–20]. However, for supported acid ionic liquid catalysts, the main problem faced is to increase the loading and dispersibility of ionic liquids on the carrier [21,22]. Hence, the design of high-loading and high-dispersibility catalysts rich in acidic active centers to meet the requirement of high catalytic activity has aroused interest of researchers. Polymeric acidic ionic liquids (PAILs), combined with acidic ILs units and a polymeric backbone, can act as dual roles of polymers and ionic liquids. The active components can be well dispersibility in the famework of PILs. Meanwhile, the high loading of active components can be easily realized by adjusting the ratios of polymerized monomers [23–28]. The solid catalyst, separated from the reaction system, usually depends on the centrifugal separation or filtration [29–31]. This process has some problems of high-energy consumption and mass loss. In order to enhance the separation efficiency of the catalyst from the reaction systems, it is an ideal method to make the solid catalyst magnetic and utilize the external magnetic field to accelerate its rapid separation from the reaction systems. Especially, the interest lies in the immobilization of acidic PILs on magnetic supports that possess both good activity and recyclability. In this work, a magnetically recyclable acid catalyst Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL was prepared through the polymerization of 1-vinyl-3-(3-sulfopropyl) imidazolium hydrogen sulfate, Fe3O4@SiO2@MPS and divinyl benzene. γ-methacryloyloxy trimethoxysilane was applied to modify silica coated Fe3O4 composite (Fe3O4@SiO2) with the purpose of offering vinyl functional group. [SO3H-(CH2)3-VIM][HSO4] was immobilized on the surface of Fe3O4@SiO2 by copolymerizing with crosslinking agent divinylbenzene, giving the magnetic poly(acidic ionic liquid) catalyst (Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL) that was used for the esterification of oleic acid with ethanol to prepare biodiesel. Moreover, response surface methodology (RSM) was applied to optimize the reaction parameters, such as catalyst amount, reaction time, etc. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents Tetraethl silicate (TEOS), ammonium hydroxide (25∼28 %), sodium acetate anhydrous, 1-vinylimidazole, sulfuric acid(95～98 %), oleic acid (85 %), anhydrous iron (III) chloride were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propylmethacrylate (MPS), divinyl benzene (DVB), sodium citrate, 1,3-propanesultone, ethylene glycol, azodiisobutyronitrile (99 %) were brought from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. All the reagents used were analytically pure and did not require further treatment unless stated. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of Brønsted ionic liquid monomer [SO3H-(CH2)3-VIM][HSO4] 0.2 mol of 1-vinylimidazole was dissolved in ethyl acetate and placed in an ice-water bath. The equimolar amount of 1,3-propanesultone was added dropwise within 10 min, and the mixture was kept stirring for 24 h. The obtained solid was then filtrated, washed with ethanol and dried in vacuum to obtain a white solid powder. Subsequently, the obtained precursor was dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water, equimolar sulfuric acid was added dropwise, and the resulting clear liquid was stirred at 60 °C for 12 h in N2 atmosphere. After the removal of water and impurities and dried in vacuum, wine-colored viscous 1-vinyl-3-(3-sulfopropyl) imidazolium hydrogen sulfate [SO3H-(CH2)3-VIM][HSO4] was obtained. 2.2.2 Synthesis of magnetic Fe3O4@SiO2@MPS support 16 mmol of FeCl3 and 3.2 mmol of trisodium citrate were dissolved in 120 mL of ethylene glycol under vigorous stirring for 30 min. 12 mmol of sodium acetate was added afterwards and vigorously stirred for another 30 min. The obtained yellow solution was then transferred to a 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 200 °C for 10 h. The magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticle was collected after it was washed with deionized water and ethanol and dried in vacuum. 1.0 g of Fe3O4 was ultrasonically dispersed into the mixture of 160 mL ethanol, 2.0 mL ammonium hydroxide and 40 mL deionized water. The dropping rate of 1.0 mL ethyl silicate was adjusted to ensure that it was added within 10 min. The Fe3O4@SiO2 was obtained after stirring for 12 h at room temperature. Subsequently, Fe3O4@SiO2 was scattered in the mixture of 4 mL, 28 % ammonia solution and 100 mL ethanol. Finally, 20 mmol MPS was added and kept stirring for another 24 h, Fe3O4@SiO2@MPS was collected. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL 3.1 g [SO3H-(CH2)3-VIM][HSO4], 0.5 g of magnetic carrier Fe3O4@SiO2 and 1.3 g divinyl benzene (DVB) were dispersed in anhydrous ethanol. After deoxygenating with N2, 0.1 g of initiator AIBN was dropped in the above solution. With the protection of N2 atmosphere, the radical polymerization process was carried out at 80 °C for 24 h. The formed precipitate was magnetically obtained, washed and dried, giving magnetic material grafted acidic poly (ionic liquid) catalyst that was abbreviated as Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL. The entire synthesis process was described in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained from a Rigaku Smartlab X-ray diffraction meter. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded by a Hitachi S4800 field-emission scanning electron microscope. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were performed on the Thermo Electron Nicolet-6700 spectrometer. The magnetic hysteresis loops were measured by a 7407 vibrating sample magnetometer. Thermogravimetry (TG) analysis were measured by STA409. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained by JEM-2100. 2.4 Experimental design The optimal reaction conditions were obtained by response surface methodology (RSM). In order to assess the interaction effects of reaction time (X1, h), molar ratio (X2, mol/mol), and catalyst amount (X3, wt%, depended on the weight of oleic acid) on the oleic acid conversion (Y), a three factor, three level Box-Behnken design was selected. The reaction temperature was set as 90 °C and the reaction was carried out in an open environment. Three independent variables were performed at three levels, namely the high-level associated plus signs (+1), the center value of zero (0) and the low-level minus signs (−1). The detailed ranges and the levels of variables were listed in Table 1 . To correlate the dependent variable with the independent ones and fit the conversion of oleic acid, a quadratic polynomial equation, showed in Eq. (1), was applied. (1) Y = λ 0 + ∑ i = 1 3 λ i x i + ∑ i = 1 3 λ i i x i 2 + ∑ i < j 3 λ i j x i x j Where λ 0 , λ i , λ i i , λ i j , Y were respectively the constant term, the liner effect term, the squared effect term, the interaction effect term, and the response variable based on oleic acid conversion. 2.5 Esterification reaction A certain amount of ethanol, Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL and 20 mmol oleic acid were respectively added in a three-necked flask with a reflux condenser. The reaction temperature was set at 90 °C (Fig. S1). After the reaction was over, the magnetic catalyst was collected using an external magnet. Meanwhile, the conversion of oleic acid was analyzed by a gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector. All the experiments were done in triplicate. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL To illustrate the crystal structures, the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed. The related results of pure Fe3O4, Fe3O4@SiO2, Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL and the recovered catalyst were presented in Fig. 2 . Obviously, some characteristic diffraction peaks appeared in pure Fe3O4 sample, ascribed to cubic inverse spinel Fe3O4 (Fig. 2a). As for Fe3O4@SiO2 (Fig. 2b), the peaks at around 20∼25° and over 30° can be respectively corresponded to the amorphous silica shell and Fe3O4 core. Fig. 2c and d showed similar patterns with Fe3O4@SiO2, illustrating that the poly (ionic liquid) matrix was of amorphous structure and the catalyst structure was maintained during reaction process. The FT-IR spectra of pure ionic liquid [SO3H-(CH2)3-VIM][HSO4], Fe3O4, Fe3O4@SiO2, Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL, recovered Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL were presented in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3a, a peak at around 595 cm−1 was the FeO stretching vibration of Fe3O4. Meanwhile, the peak centered at approximately 1088 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of SiOSi was also observed. This illustrated that silica was successfully grafted on the surface of Fe3O4 nanospheres (Fig. 3b). For [SO3H-(CH2)3-VIM][HSO4] (Fig. 3c), the typical asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of SO appeared at around 1190 and 1042 cm−1. Moreover, the stretching vibrations of SO were observed at around 886 cm-1. The peaks at around 1458, 1554 and 1575 cm-1 could be ascribed to the CH asymmetric bending vibration, the CN and CC double bonds stretching vibrations of the imidazole ring. In addition, the peak at around 1654 cm−1 corresponded to CC stretching vibration of the vinyl group could be clearly observed. Simultaneously, the similar peaks also appeared in the same position in Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL (Fig. 3d), indicating that functional groups of ionic liquid were reserved during the polymerization process and acidic poly (ionic liquid) was grafted on magnetic support Fe3O4@SiO2. Furthermore, the FT-IR spectra of recovered catalyst was same to that of the fresh one (Fig. 3e). The morphology and microstructure analyses were conducted through SEM and TEM, and the results were showed in Fig. 4 . The Fe3O4@SiO2 particles turned out to be spherical with a core-shell structure (Fig. 4a and b). The inner Fe3O4 core (the size was about 300 nm) acted as magnetic switch and the outer silica shell (the thickness was about 30 nm) worked as the protection for Fe3O4 core from decay in harsh reaction circumstances. Meanwhile, it could be clearly seen that SiO2 was evenly wrapped on the surface of Fe3O4, which provided the possibility of MPS uniform grafting and further led to the uniform dispersion of ionic liquids on the surface of Fe3O4@SiO2@MPS. Fig. 4c and d clearly revealed that in the Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL, ionic liquid monomer polymerized on the carrier surface and Fe3O4@SiO2 particles were totally embedded in poly (ionic liquid) matrix. The spongy-structure would greatly help to increase the exposure of active sites of catalyst, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Meanwhile, the SEM (Fig. 4e) and TEM (Fig. 4f) of the recovered Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL showed that the core-shell structure of Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL and the sponge structure of PIL remained after several repeated use, implying that Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL possessed excellent stability in the liquid-phase reaction. The vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) was used to study the magnetic properties of samples. As shown in Fig. 5 , the saturation magnetization value of Fe3O4@SiO2 was approximately 40.8 emu/g. Due to the existence of nonmagnetic poly (ionic liquid) matrix, the saturation magnetization value of Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL reduced to 14.3 emu/g, which still ensured rapid and thorough catalyst separation in an external magnetic field (less than 1 min) without filtration or centrifugation (Fig. 5 inset). Both samples exhibited superparamagnetic properties and no remanence could be detected. 3.2 RSM analysis The experimental matrix design and the corresponding responses based on experiments put forward by the Box-Behnken design (BBD) for the esterification of oleic acid and ethanol were presented in Table 2 . It could be clearly seen that the predicted values of the conversion were similar to the experimental ones and within an acceptable variance range. Moreover, the parallel experiments were carried out under the same reaction conditions to confirm that the results of the Box-Behnken design (BBD) for the esterification of oleic acid and ethanol were reproducible with the relative deviations within the allowable range (Table S1). Relied on the experimental data and taken into account the coded factors, the fitted second-order polynomial equation (Eq. (2)) can illustrate the empirical relationships between the independent variable and the response. (2) Y = 89.06 + 3.75X1 + 4.35X2 + 7.05X3 − 0.97X1X2 − 1.38X1X3 + 1.43X2X3 − 10.54X1 2 − 6.54X2 2 − 4.89X3 2 Where Y, X1, X2, and X3 represented the oleic acid conversion, the coded values of process variables (the reaction time, the molar ratio of ethanol/acid, and the catalyst amount), respectively. Based on Eq. (2), the process variables had a linear and quadratic relationship with the conversion of oleic acid. To assess the adequacy of the model, analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted to verify the main interaction influences of each other on the oleic acid conversion. As shown in Table 3 , the Model F-value of 63.99 proved that the model was reliable. When the values of “Prob > F” were less than 0.05, model terms were significant. Thus, it could be concluded that the independent variables (X1, X2, X3) and the corresponding quadratic terms (X1 2, X2 2, X3 2) were all significant model terms. The “Pred R-Squared” (0.8174) was well consistent with the “Adj R-Squared” (0.9726). “Adeq Precision” was used to express the signal to noise ratio. When the ratio was over 4, it was desirable. The ratio of 23.381 exhibited a sufficient signal, conforming that this model could be applied to navigate the design space. To visualize the relationships between the response and variables and determine the optimum values of variables by Design Expert, the regression equation was presented in the manner with three-dimensional surfaces. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the conversion of oleic acid increased smoothly when the molar ratio of ethanol to acid increased from 6:1 to 11:1, while decreased gradually when the molar ratio exceeded 12 within any reaction time. The positive effect of the molar ratio of ethanol to acid was ascribed to that ethanol worked as both solvent and reactant in this system. However, excess ethanol could cover the active sites of the catalyst, thus blocking the protonation of oleic acid at the active site of the catalyst. Meanwhile, the oleic acid conversion drastically increased when the reaction time increased from 2.0 to 4.5 h. Fig. 6b described the synergistic effect between reaction time and catalyst amount on the conversion of oleic acid. As was known, more catalyst would provide more active sites, enhancing the catalytic conversion of oleic acid. Obviously, the conversion of oleic acid increased when the catalyst amount changed from 5 to 10 wt%. The interaction effect between molar ratio and catalyst amount on the conversion of oleic acid was shown in Fig. 6c. Same as the other two response surfaces, this one was convex to seek the maximum of conversion of oleic acid. To obtain the optimum reaction parameters, optimization was proceeded based on the desirability function. The related results were shown in in Table 4 . Under the optimum reaction condition, the obtained maximum conversion of oleic acid was 92.8 %. Meanwhile, a verification experiment was carried out to illustrate the adequacy of the model that was used to predict the maximum conversion of oleic acid. The average value of oleic acid conversion under three independent experiments was 92.1 %, which was well accorded with the predicted value. This further confirmed the proposed statistical model was adequate to predict the conversion of oleic acid. 3.3 Catalytic performance assessment Fig. 7 summarized the esterification performance of oleic acid and ethanol over different catalysts. Without any catalyst, the conversion of oleic acid was low(less than 5 % after 5 h reaction). Comparatively, Fe3O4@SiO2 showed no obvious catalytic activity. As the homogeneous catalyst, pure ionic liquid [SO3H-(CH2)3-VIM][HSO4] had a high catalytic activity and the conversion of oleic acid was about 90 %. However, it had an obvious difficulty in the separation of catalyst and product. Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL, as a magnetically heterogeneous catalyst with acidity of 1.72 mmol H+ g−1, exhibited a better catalytic activity and stability. Moreover, the catalytic performance for biodiesel production over Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL and other kinds of solid catalysts were compared. Obviously, the conversion of oleic acid and the yield of ethyl oleate and methyl oleate over Fe3O4@SiO2@poly(sulfonated vinylimidazolium ionic liquid) catalyst were comparable with those of reported solid catalyst [32–37], as displayed in Table 5 . 3.4 Catalyst reusability and universality The reusability of the catalyst was an important indicator of catalyst performance evaluation. Herein, the reusability of Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst for the esterification of oleic acid was performed under the optimized reaction conditions (Fig. 8 ). After each experiment, the Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst was separated using an external magnetic field, and then the obtained catalyst was washed and dried before being used in the next recycle. From Fig. 8, the conversion of oleic acid decreased slightly from 92.1 % to 89.2 % after six recycles, which indicated that the prepared Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst had good stability. Meanwhile, the slight decrease in catalytic activity might be attributed to the mass loss of catalyst during the washing and transfer process. To further investigate the applicability of the developed Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst for the esterification, a series of alcohols (methanol, ethanol and n-propanol) and acids (oleic acid and stearic acid) were examined, as shown in Fig. S2. For oleic acid and stearic acid, the conversion over Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst changed little and kept over 90 %. However, when the alkyl chain length of alcohols increased from methanol to n-propanol, the conversion of oleic acid over Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst decreased. It could be clearly seen that Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst was an excellent candidate for esterification. 4 Conclusions In summary, magnetically recyclable catalyst was fabricated after the sponge-like structure of poly (ionic liquid) matrix formed on the surface of the support Fe3O4/SiO2. The catalyst possessed open active sites to reactants and high magnetization value (14.3 emu/g), affording a simple catalyst recovery in an external magnetic field. Owing to the layer structure of poly(sulfonated vinylimidazolium ionic liquid), the obtained Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL catalyst with a high loading amount of active component, ensured that it possessed good catalytic performance in the esterification of oleic acid for biodiesel production. The conversion of oleic acid is 92.1 % and the methyl oleate yield of 92.1 % under the optimal reaction conditions. Moreover, the catalyst also exhibited good stability and reusability. The present study put forward a promising strategy to design a magnetically recyclable poly(ionic liquid) catalyst as an efficient acid catalyst for biodiesel production, which might open novel vistas for exploring magnetically recyclable poly(ionic liquid)-based catalysts in various applications. coredata.dc:description: Construction of an efficient and separable Bronsted acid catalyst to realize one-pot conversion from low-value oils to biodiesel has been a hot and difficult spot in recent years. Herein, a novel magnetically recyclable catalyst was fabricated by grafting the sponge-like structure of poly (ionic liquid) on the surface of support Fe3O4/SiO2. The grafting copolymerization of dual-acidic ionic liquid (sulfonated vinylimidazolium ionic liquid) on the Fe3O4/SiO2 was beneficial to enhance the strong acidity of the magnetic carrier and also made dual-acidic ionic liquid own excellent separation characteristics. The characterization results of the prepared composite showed that a sponge-like structure of poly(ionic liquid) was wrapped on the outer surface of Fe3O4@SiO2, thereby providing more active sites to reactants. Meanwhile, the catalyst possessed high magnetization value (14.3 emu/g) that resulted in the simple and rapid separation from the reaction system through an external magnetic field. Benefiting from the synergy effect between dual-acidic poly(ionic liquids) and magnetic carrier, Fe3O4@SiO2@PIL exhibited good catalytic performance with the oleic acid conversion of 92.1 % and the methyl oleate yield of 92.1 %. Besides, the recycled catalyst showed no significant loss in the catalytic activity after repeated use for six times.
coredata.dc:title: Core-shell magnetic nanomaterial grafted spongy-structured poly (ionic liquid): A recyclable brönsted acid catalyst for biodiesel production
